There's no reason you couldn't implement your suggestions yourself quite
easily.  Try this:

1) define assertUnimplemented() method that throws a unique
Error type and call as appropriate.
2) define an abort() method that throws a unique Error type.
3) create your own TestCase superclass that all your test classes
inherit from, and define setUp follows:
final void setUp()
{
  try {
    setUpImpl();
  } catch (Throwable t) {
	abort("Error in setUp", t);
  }
}
Your subclasses define setUpImpl. Handle tearDown similarly.

4) Define a TestListener that defines addError() to record results in
separate buckets according to the Error thrown.  Include a method to
summarize the output.

5) Hook the TestListener into a TestRunner, and you're done!

I realize this seems a little nuts, but the point is there are enough
hooks in JUnit as-is to implement this rather easily.  The main problem
is that JUnit's TestRunners don't let you attach arbitrary
TestListeners.  I have implemented my own ExtensibleTestRunner that does
do this and have also defined a TestRunListener interface that extends
TestListener with startRun() and endRun() methods.  The result is an
extremely flexible TestRunner that can be extended dynamically according
to need.  I can pick and choose output styles according to what
TestListener I use, and your rebucketing scheme would be simple to
implement.  Let mw know if you're interested in the source.
